title: Hacker group posts hundreds of law officer records
content:
BOSTON ‚Äî Authorities were investigating Saturday the online posting by a hacker group of the personal information of hundreds of federal agents and police officers apparently stolen from websites affiliated with alumni of the FBI's National Academy. The Associated Press counted at least 1,400 unique records of employees of the FBI, Secret Service, Capitol Police, U.S. Park Police and other federal agencies as well as police and sheriffs' deputies in North Carolina and Florida. The records included home addresses and phone numbers, emails and employers' names.
Hackers posted hundreds of law enforcement officers' records online, authorities said. Al Drago / Bloomberg via Getty Images file The FBI National Academy Associates said in a statement that the information, posted late Thursday, appears to come from the websites of three local chapters of the nonprofit, which claims nearly 17,000 members nationwide and in 174 countries.
It said it was working with federal authorities to investigate.
The group said its national database was unaffected. It said the three affected chapters were using third-party software but said it was "too early to determine if this impacted the breach."
"If it is determined that there has been felonious activity, we well prosecute the culprits to the fullest extent of the law," said the group, which is based in Quantico, Virginia, home to the academy.
The AP is not identifying the hackers' website. A linked Twitter account says the group is based in Ukraine.
The hack was first reported by the news site TechCrunch.
Associated Press

title: 2 children killed as powerful storms, including reported tornadoes, hit Texas
content: Weather 5 people killed as powerful storms sweep across southern U.S. Two children died in Texas when a tree fell on the car they were in, and a boy in Louisiana drowned in a drainage area, officials said. April 14, 2019 01:33 Breaking News Emails April 14, 2019, 2:18 AM UTC / Updated April 14, 2019, 4:44 PM UTC By Phil Helsel and Amy Calvin At least five people, including three children, were killed Saturday in powerful storms that swept across the southern U.S., authorities said. In Texas two children, ages 8 and 3, died when a tree fell on a car Saturday afternoon, trapping them inside, according to the Angelina County Sheriff's Department. They were pronounced dead at the scene. In West Monroe, Louisiana, a 13-year-old boy drowned in a drainage area in what officials believe was a weather-related incident, said Glen Springfield, spokesman for the Ouachita Parish Sheriff's Office. Several streets were closed in the city of around 13,000 and a flood warning had been issued for the area, officials said. A fourth person who died in the storms was a woman killed by weather-related debris near the community of Weches in Houston County, Texas, the sheriff‚Äôs office said. The age of the woman was not released. Weches is west of Nacogdoches. A man in his mid-to-late 80s also died over the weekend in Monroe County, Mississippi, according to volunteer fire coordinator Terry Tucker. Tucker did not disclose the exact cause of his death other than to say it was weather-related. 83 million people under threat of tornadoes, strong winds and flooding April 14, 2019 00:59 In Franklin, Texas, a tornado touched down and destroyed homes Saturday, injuring about a dozen people described as walking wounded and sending two people to the emergency room, Robertson County Sheriff Gerald Yezak said. "A strip of homes on the other side of town over here are completely gone, just gone, everything is gone," Robertson County Emergency Management Coordinator Billy Huggins said. The National Weather Service's Fort Worth office tweeted that after a preliminary damage assessment, the tornado in Robertson County was estimated to have a peak intensity of EF-3 with winds of 140 mph. The damage survey will continue over the next several days, the service said. Huggins said he got a call from the National Weather Service around 11:20 a.m. about a storm system that was on the ground and headed towards Franklin. "We started trying to get people activated to get eyeballs on it, and by then the thing was moving fast and it went right through town,‚Äù he said. The weather service said severe thunderstorms from east Texas to Arkansas were possible Saturday, and the threat of severe weather will then affect the Ohio Valley into the southeastern U.S. on Sunday. Angelina County is around 120 miles north of Houston, and Franklin, a town of about 1,500, is about 110 miles northwest of Houston. In Alto, Texas, Marry Lamar with the volunteer fire department said a suspected tornado touched down Saturday, and several people were injured. The front wall of a gym at a school was blown off as were windows and doors at a fire house, Lamar said. Video posted on social media showed trees and power lines down and homes damaged in the town of just over 1,200 people. Meteorologist John Moore said a possible twister touched down Saturday in the Vicksburg, Mississippi, area, the Associated Press reported. No injuries were reported, but officials said several businesses and vehicles were damaged. Vicksburg Mayor George Flaggs Jr. told NBC affiliate WLBT the storms ‚Äújust came in all at once‚Äù with heavy winds and rain. "It was like it was a war zone; I‚Äôve never seen nothing like it my life," Flaggs told the station. "It looked like everyone was safe,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúIt's unbelievable. We‚Äôve been blessed. What we‚Äôre going to do now is begin to recover." He said power crews were working to restore electricity to around 1,700 customers, and he asked people to not panic and to use caution when using alternate power sources like generators. A gas station is damaged following severe weather, Saturday, April 13, 2019 in Vicksburg, Miss. Courtland Wells / The Vicksburg Post via AP A meteorologist with Alabama's emergency management agency warned that "supercells and potential tornadoes" could enter the western part of the state Sunday. "Unfortunately, the western half of the state may have a few tornadoes before sunrise while many people are in bed," meteorologist Jim Stefkovich said in a statement . In Roberston County, Texas, the damage in Franklin was called ‚Äúdevastating‚Äù by Huggins, the emergency management coordinator. He said that everyone has been accounted for. "To this small town of Franklin, it's very devastating, how we're going to get people help to restore their homes that don‚Äôt have insurance or what have you, it's going to be pretty difficult," he said. "It's going to be a little difficult putting it back together, but we'll do it." Phil Helsel Phil Helsel is a reporter for NBC News. Amy Calvin

title: What child-free women need to know about managing their careers
content: Business Culture What child-free women need to know about managing their careers About 14 percent of women in the age bracket 40 to 44 ‚Äî generally considered the end of the childbearing years ‚Äî are not mothers. Oprah Winfrey, Stevie Nicks, and Condoleezza Rice. Reuters, AP, Getty Get the Know Your Value newsletter. SUBSCRIBE April 12, 2019, 6:01 PM GMT By Julianne Pepitone Kate Kaufmann always planned to have children. Never did she imagine that she‚Äôd spend years researching and writing about women who ‚Äî just like her ‚Äî aren‚Äôt mothers in a culture that expects it. Over the decades after her infertility journey, Kaufmann found women who aren‚Äôt mothers (by choice or circumstance) face unique challenges when it comes to managing their careers. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs a part of the conversation we don‚Äôt know how to have,‚Äù said Kaufmann, author of the new book ‚ÄúDo You Have Kids? Life When the Answer is No.‚Äù ‚ÄúThere are stigmas and stereotypes on both sides, and it‚Äôs a shame, because as women the experiences we all have are so rich." Kaufmann and other experts Know Your Value spoke to noted we don‚Äôt even have a great word to describe these women in conversations about parenthood. Non-mothers? Child-free or childless? They all describe women in terms of the absence of motherhood. According to Kate Kaufmann, "There's an assumption that if you don't have kids you have more time available." DelPozo Photography What's more, there's a pervasive double standard for women. Melanie Notkin, author of ‚ÄúOtherhood: Modern Women Finding A New Kind of Happiness ," who is childless by circumstance, feels people sometimes think that means "I am a quote-unquote ‚Äòcareer woman.‚Äô‚Äù About 14 percent of women in the age bracket 40 to 44 ‚Äî generally considered the end of the childbearing years ‚Äî are not mothers, according to a Pew Research Center analysis of U.S. Census Bureau data . In the celebrity realm, several high-profile women have proudly discussed their child-free status in recent years, including Oprah Winfrey, Lily Tomlin, Condoleezza Rice and Stevie Nicks. Whether you‚Äôre childless, child-free, or unsure about whether you want to or will become a mother, here‚Äôs what you need to know about managing your career. Career opportunities Increased ability to take career risks: Without the inherent ties of kids who depend on you, taking risks can be more appealing compared to those who are parents. Jenn Seva, 48, who works in business development at a gaming company in Seattle and does not have children by choice, recalled the flexibility to consider a job that would have taken her away from the man who would later become her husband for more than two years. ‚ÄúI have the privilege to allow myself to be ... well, what some people stigmatize as selfish,‚Äù Seva said. ‚ÄúBut I‚Äôve given myself the power to prioritize what I want, and put that at the center of my decisions.‚Äù Jenn Seva, 48, lives in Seattle and says she is childfree by choice. Holla Roa Higher earnings: Without the need for maternity leave or taking significant time off to raise children, women without kids are more likely to have continuous careers. Some analyses of the gender wage gap conclude this difference is key: A 2014 study that analyzed pay data from the Bureau of Labor Statistics found that married women without children earn 93 cents to a child-free man‚Äôs dollar. But married mothers with young kids earn only 76 cents on that dollar. Potentially reduced risk of burnout: Anyone, with or without children, can spend too much time working. And we all have personal lives to balance with the responsibilities of the office. But for those who aren‚Äôt parents, work days aren‚Äôt punctuated by helping with homework or lengthy bedtime routines. Generally, your downtime is your own to de-stress, unplug and do what you feel like. Jane Terzis, 68, is a fine artist living in Portland. Courtesy of Jane Terzis. Jane Terzis, 68, a fine artist who now lives in Portland, Oregon, enjoyed a fruitful career as an art professor, prison arts program director, yoga studio owner, freelance illustrator and more. Terzis is childless by circumstance after spending 10 years on an infertility journey that included traveling from Juneau to Seattle for treatments. ‚ÄúDays in academia are long, and for a few years there I came home practically falling on my face every night,‚Äù Terzis said. ‚ÄúBut I came home to a husband who‚Äôd made me dinner and then we could relax and watch a movie, or I could go right to bed. Of course I worked with mothers who managed it, but looking back, it‚Äôs really hard to imagine getting through it while caring for a child." Workplace pitfalls to watch for Assumptions that you can work nights, weekends, whenever: Colleagues and bosses may assume women without kids are always available for that weekend shift, the late meeting or the overnight call with India. ‚ÄúThere‚Äôs an assumption that if you don‚Äôt have kids you have more time available,‚Äù Kaufmann said. ‚ÄúOn a general level that might be true, but of course these women have their own rich lives. [In researching the book,] I was struck by how many women I interviewed are deeply involved in their communities. Or you might have a parent with dementia, or health concerns yourself. Your time is not less valuable.‚Äù Notkin, the ‚ÄúOtherhood‚Äù author, cautioned that women may have to speak up. ‚ÄúI actually had to say to my [former] boss, having these meetings at 6 and 7 p.m. isn‚Äôt helping my own career and dreams and it isn‚Äôt sustainable for me,‚Äù said Notkin, who now runs her own business. Melanie Notkin, author of "Otherhood: Modern Women Finding A New Kind of Happiness." Ana Gambuto ‚ÄúI actually had to say to my boss, having these meetings at 6 and 7 p.m. isn‚Äôt helping my own career and dreams and it isn‚Äôt sustainable for me,‚Äù Notkin said. ‚ÄúBecause people assume things about a female employee ‚Äî that no one needs her, that she has nothing going on ‚Äî the reality is that sometimes you need to address it. It doesn‚Äôt have to be confrontational, just matter-of-fact with examples.‚Äù Feelings of ‚Äúotherhood‚Äù: Particularly at workplaces with several women of childbearing age, ‚Äúthere will be conversations you‚Äôll feel left out of and celebrations where you'll feel sidelined,‚Äù Kaufmann said. Office baby showers may be particularly difficult for people who are childless by circumstance. Terzis, the artist and former professor, once experienced a ‚Äúbaby boom‚Äù in which five of the 17 faculty in her department were expecting babies at the same time: ‚ÄúBaby showers were tough,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúIt wasn‚Äôt until 10 years ago, when I was nearly 60, that I finally gave myself permission to not attend any more baby showers.‚Äù Beyond the one-off celebrations, constant feelings of being outside of the peer group culture can be even more challenging. ‚ÄúThere‚Äôs a group of moms at work who definitely bond over that; they have a friendship on this very intimate level,‚Äù said Seva, the gaming company manager. ‚ÄúIf a new mom is coming back to work and the breast pump isn‚Äôt working, that‚Äôs a private thing they‚Äôre going to discuss. I get that. But the result is that some people are in the inner circle, and I as a non-mom am on the outside.‚Äù Connecting with other colleagues outside of the mom group can be a way to cope. Finding other common ground to bond with the women who are mothers is another effective tool. Stigmas and stereotypes that can bleed into work: But those mothers may inadvertently make assumptions about what their child-free and childless counterparts want to hear about. Several women told Know Your Value they would have been happy to hear about their colleagues‚Äô kids, but they felt people assume they don‚Äôt care or even that they hate children. They talked about being left out not only of first birthday parties in their social lives, but discussions at the workplace. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs like, ‚ÄòOf course I care what‚Äôs going on with you! You‚Äôre my colleague!‚Äô‚Äù Seva said. ‚ÄúThere are times I‚Äôd be happy to pick up any slack, or take that late call, to help you out. But I can‚Äôt if I don‚Äôt know about it.‚Äù Seva compared it to ‚Äúframing the world like a sitcom: We put people in their little boxes and make assumptions about the way this kind of person is. To change the conversation, you have to be part of it ‚Äî and often, we don‚Äôt even make it to that step.‚Äù The decisions and circumstances surrounding parenthood are deeply personal, so it isn‚Äôt surprising that the conversations are difficult ‚Äî especially at the office. But, Kaufmann agreed, that‚Äôs why stigmas fester and stereotypes persist. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs a conversation that doesn‚Äôt feel comfortable, which means there‚Äôs room for all of us to learn and explore,‚Äù Kaufmann said. ‚ÄúThere is inequity on both sides, and stereotypes about all kinds of women. To change it, that means stepping right into it.‚Äù MORE FROM knowyourvalue

title: For Northern Ireland, 'Game of Thrones' is much more than a popular TV show
content:
BALLYHORNAN, Northern Ireland ‚Äî Will Mulhall was an 18-year-old lifeguard on the coast of Northern Ireland‚Äôs County Down when he took his life savings and bought two Northern Inuit puppies. He wanted big dogs, he said, and was drawn to the wolf-like appearance of the breed. A few weeks later Mulhall received a call from HBO that would change his life ‚Äî and that of his dogs.
Odin and Thor are now better known to "Game of Thrones" fans as Grey Wind and Summer, the dire wolves of central characters Robb and Bran Stark.
Their roles in the show transformed the dogs from household pets into superstars.
They now have their own Instagram account, have been visited by over 400,000 tourists and are insured for more than $1 million each.
For locals like Mulhall, the show is much more than an epic tale of battles, ice zombies and dragons.
Related Opinion Opinion 'Game of Thrones' trailer breakdown: What HBO does ‚Äî and does not ‚Äî want us to know about season eight Over the course of eight seasons, "Game of Thrones" was filmed in more than 49 locations throughout Northern Ireland. From historic castles to rugged coastlines and ancient forests, the sites have grown popular with fans eager to visit ‚Äî and meet the real dire wolves.
Ace Del Cruz was so excited he could barely speak after petting Odin and Thor. ‚ÄúSeeing the dire wolves, you get to pet them, just seeing them is so amazing," said Del Cruz, a Philippines native and show enthusiast. "I can‚Äôt even pronounce what I want to say.‚Äù
‚ÄúIt is kind of surreal that they were in ‚ÄòGame of Thrones‚Äô and they are here,‚Äù said Susan Hewitt from Essex, England.
Tourism has become big business for Northern Ireland, with the show helping to attract 120,000 visitors a year and bringing in $40 million annually to the local economy.
Mulhall now runs a successful company, DireWolf Tours, that in addition to featuring his beloved dogs takes fans to key sites across the region.
‚ÄúIt has taken over our lives,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúEvery day ‚ÄòGame of Thrones‚Äô is playing some part in my life, and it just got bigger and bigger and madder and madder and it keeps going on!‚Äù
William van der Kells runs a similar business nearby at Castle Ward, which is better known to "Thrones" viewers as Winterfell ‚Äî the home of the Stark family. Van der Kells teaches tourists to shoot arrows and throw axes.
Related TV TV Five minutes with Ned Stark: His ‚ÄòGame of Thrones‚Äô predictions and whether he'll return Not everyone is so gushing about the show's impact on their ancient land. Some have raised concerns about how the sudden influx of tourists may affect the conservation of historic sites.
Near the village of Armoy, an avenue of 200-year-old beach trees known as Dark Hedges was used as the show's "Kingsroad." So many fans flocked to the site that it became choked with traffic, something one campaign group labeled a "national disgrace" that's "slowly killing a national treasure."
Closing the Dark Hedges to vehicle traffic - how soon is now? A national disgrace slowly killing a national treasure. @CausewayCouncil pic.twitter.com/2fJCs3y1UT
‚Äî NI Greenways (@nigreenways) April 17, 2017 For many, however, the positive attention is preferable to the way things were before. For decades, Northern Ireland struggled to draw visitors, with many people associating the country with the decadeslong sectarian conflict known as "the Troubles," even after it largely ended in 1998.
Van der Kells believes "Game of Thrones" has helped alter that perception. ‚ÄúWe had 40 years of violence. People have got killed, maimed, injured. Now we have fantasy violence, and it is bringing in more money.‚Äù
Rosemary McHugh of Tourism NI, the government's official tourism body, agreed. ‚ÄúIt has given us that new narrative ‚Ä¶ which makes Northern Ireland a more exciting place," she said. "It has put our landscapes and our heritage out there in an exciting way.‚Äù
How Brexit could push N. Ireland to the brink Jan. 11, 2019 06:14 The show has brought benefits beyond tourism, too, providing ample employment opportunities.
Nearly 13,000 extras have been used during shooting in the country according to HBO, including Mulhall and his brothers. Their father, boasting a long silver beard, played a Dothraki slave-master.
Much of the cast, including stars Kit Harrington and Maisie Williams, have been guests at The Cuen Inn in the village of Strongmore.
The owner, Caroline McEarlean, now serves a popular "Game of Thrones banquet" complete with alcohol served in locally produced goblets modeled after those used by the show‚Äôs wealthy Lannister family.
This attention to detail has paid off. ‚ÄúIt is phenomenal. It is the most significant financial impact that in our 29 years of business we have ever experienced,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúAnd it‚Äôs not going away.‚Äù
Everyone from casting agents to taxidermists has enjoyed a bit of the action. The total benefit to the Northern Irish economy is estimated to be over $240 million over the past decade.
But while winter has arrived for the show's characters, Northern Ireland residents are confident the "Game of Thrones" boom will not die when season 8 ends.
‚ÄúThere is going to be a legacy," van der Kells said. "The thing has got such cult status now I think people will come over and over again."
Kiko Itasaka Kiko Itasaka is a producer based in London.

title: Soccer in the spotlight as Europe grapples with racism on and off the field
content: World Soccer in the spotlight as Europe grapples with racism on and off the field A growing number of young stars are speaking out as stories of players facing abuse from fans, both on the field and online, have gained attention in recent weeks. England's Raheem Sterling celebrates scoring their fifth goal at Podgorica City Stadium, Podgorica, Montenegro. Carl recine / Reuters Breaking News Emails Get breaking news alerts and special reports. The news and stories that matter, delivered weekday mornings. SUBSCRIBE April 14, 2019, 7:29 AM GMT By Patrick Smith LONDON ‚Äî At 24, Linton Harris‚Äô soccer career is over. But it's not injury that's caused him to hang up his cleats, it's racism. While playing for the tiny amateur team Wymeswold FC in a local county cup final last Wednesday ‚Äî a far cry from the glitz and glamour of England's Premier League ‚Äî Harris claims he was subjected to racist shouts, including monkey noises. Harris was later sent off. "Typical black man, ruining the game," someone was heard to shout from the crowd as he made his way from the field. What happened next was almost unheard of: A teammate was then sent off for supporting Harris ‚Äî he was appealing to the referee, who had not stopped the game ‚Äî and the entire team then walked off with 12 minutes still remaining. The game was abandoned. Harris has scored 46 goals this season, helping Wymeswold win its league. But, he says, he really is quitting. "Oh yeah, definitely, 100 percent ‚Äî I'm done with playing football altogether," he told NBC News. "It's just getting worse and worse." This story of abuse in front of a small number of fans may not grab many headlines. But it comes at a time when racism in British and European soccer is very much back in the spotlight. Stories of players facing abuse from fans, both on the field and online , have gained attention in recent weeks. It's unclear whether this is due to an increase in racist abuse around the game, or simply an increase in the attention paid to such incidents. But what does seem to be changing is that a growing number of young stars are speaking out. And Harris is not the only one considering walking away from the beautiful game after being exposed to its ugly side. Danny Rose, a Tottenham and England defender, said last week that he is looking forward to retiring so he doesn't have to deal with the abuse and all the politics that surrounds it. "At the minute, how I program myself is that I just think: 'I've got five or six more years left in football and I just can‚Äôt wait to see the back of it,'" he told the media after a number of black England players were subjected to racist chants from home fans during a game in Montenegro. "Seeing how things are done in the game at the minute, it‚Äôs just ‚Äî whatever, isn‚Äôt it? I just want to get out of it." Raheem Sterling, 24, is fed up, too. And with the added prominence that comes with each match-winning performance for Premier League giants Manchester City, he is making his voice heard. Best way to silence the haters (and yeah I mean racists) üôâüòò #2019 #getsomeeducation pic.twitter.com/ohhkOJtdey ‚Äî Raheem Sterling (@sterling7) March 25, 2019 After scoring England‚Äôs fifth goal in a 5-1 win over Montenegro, Sterling walked toward the fans with his hands to his ears ‚Äî a direct response to the racist taunting, he later confirmed. Sterling 's talent saw him first rise to prominence as a teenager. He is the subject of consistent scrutiny from the British tabloids, and many have argued that his media treatment is worse than that given to white players of his generation. A number of recent incidents on the field have prompted Sterling to become an eloquent spokesman for black players, calling for greater punishment for teams and fans who transgress. Raheem Sterling of Manchester City discusses racism, the relentlessness of media stereotypes about black players and his decision to call out both after he was racially abused during a Premier League match in December https://t.co/X7k8RMyQcC ‚Äî The New York Times (@nytimes) March 11, 2019 A spokesperson for Kick it Out, a charity devoted to fighting discrimination in the sport, told NBC News that officials rarely, if ever, follow the correct procedure when racist chanting or behavior is reported during a match. "Players are being failed by the football authorities," the spokesperson said. "Players are not being protected and it's only a matter of time before they take matters into their own hands and do things like walk off." For many, the recent instances of racist abuse are a grim reminder of the past, and a sad indictment of a soccer culture that many thought had outgrown such ugly discrimination. Trailblazing black players regularly had to endure monkey chants and banana skins being thrown at them on the field in the 1970s and the 1980s. "In football, I think we operate in what I call a 'white habitus,' which means that apart from the players, the majority of people who watch the game are white," said Jamie Cleland, a British academic at the University of South Australia, who has studied discrimination in sport. "Throughout football history whiteness has been a key part of the game." "In the 1980s, people would throw bananas at players, and what's happening now is very overt monkey chanting such as at the England vs Montenegro game ‚Äî and social media is creating another outlet for these 'fans,' to use the term broadly, to express these racist thoughts," he added. Cyril Regis was one of the first high-profile black players to make it at the elite level. "As a player, I just made sure I did not crumble from the abuse; that was my way of fighting back," he said in 2002. The idea of silencing racists on the field and then letting the authorities deal with the aftermath is popular among many professionals. England is far from alone in dealing with the problem. A recent incident in Italy went viral on social media, leading to a similar debate over how best to respond to the issue. Moise Kean ‚Äî a talented young forward for Italian champions Juventus ‚Äî gestured to opposition fans with his arms outstretched after scoring in a game earlier this month, an apparent act of defiance in reaction to racist chants. While Kean's reaction was not dissimilar to Sterling's, the response of his teammates was. Veteran defender Leonardo Bonucci said the blame for any racist taunts was split "50-50" between the fans and Kean himself. Coach Massimiliano Allegri even said Kean "shouldn't have celebrated in that manner." Their reactions were widely criticized. For his part, Sterling said in a press conference this week that walking off the pitch would only let the racists win. "To win the game would hurt them even more," he said. "They're only trying to get you down." Patrick Smith

title: The Lyrid meteor shower is back. Here's how to see April's shooting stars.
content:
April brings the return of the annual Lyrid meteor shower . Skywatchers may be able to see the shooting stars, though experts say the full moon threatens to upstage this year‚Äôs show. ‚ÄúThe light from the full moon is pretty much going to completely wash out the Lyrids this year,‚Äù Bill Cooke, a meteor expert at NASA's Marshall Space Flight Center in Huntsville, Alabama, said in an email.
The Lyrids ‚Äî so named because they appear to stream from the constellation Lyra ‚Äî begin on the evening of April 16 and continue through April 28. The action will peak on the night of April 22, when ‚Äî moonlight and weather permitting ‚Äî viewers may be able to see about 20 meteors an hour.
In some previous years, skywatchers reported seeing as many as 100 meteors an hour .
Related Space Space First-ever photo of a black hole reveals what had been unseeable Meteor showers occur when bits of fast-moving debris from a comet collide with Earth‚Äôs atmosphere as our planet travels around the sun. As the grains of rock and dust smash into air molecules, they quickly heat up to temperatures as high as 3,000 degrees Fahrenheit (1,650 degrees Celsius) ‚Äî and create dazzling streaks across the sky as they burn up.
‚ÄúI kind of like thinking about the fact that the particles burning up in our atmosphere during a shower have been orbiting the sun for centuries, finally hitting the top of our atmosphere and going out in a streak of light,‚Äù Cooke said.
In the case of the Lyrids, the debris comes from comet C/1861 G1, or Comet Thatcher, which was named for the amateur astronomer A. E. Thatcher, who first spotted the comet April 5, 1861.
No special equipment is needed to see shooting stars. "All you have to do is lie on your back and look straight up ‚Äî pretty easy,‚Äù Cooke said. Just make sure to pick a viewing spot away from city and street lights ‚Äî and put aside your smartphone.
‚ÄúObserving meteors requires letting your eyes adapt to the dark, so one does not want to be looking at the screen of a phone or tablet,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúThat also takes your attention away from the sky.‚Äù

title: For 'Game of Thrones' superfans and devoted conspiracy theorists: Similar psychology, different outcomes.
content:
On Reddit, some ‚ÄúGame of Thrones‚Äù fans subscribe to a tortuous theory that a group of old, scholarly men ‚Äî the maesters ‚Äî are part of a sprawling and hidden conspiracy to exert control over the show‚Äôs mythical kingdom. They write thousands of words to each other proving that every obscure clue adds up to a big picture that only they can see. Just a few clicks away, other Reddit users are sure that a secretive group ‚Äî the Illuminati ‚Äî is part of a sprawling and hidden conspiracy to control the real world. They do exactly the same thing.
There are some clear parallels between fan conspiracy theories and political conspiracy theories. They were once confined to the far corners of American culture, but in recent years have flourished thanks in part to internet message boards and social media, which offer anyone the opportunity to publish, debunk, rebunk and remix their own imaginary concepts and share them with like-minded theorists.
The theories, however, share more than just message boards. The psychology of groups and the internet‚Äôs propensity to amplify outlandish content and reward the people who create it has created the kind of feedback loops in which bizarre theories ‚Äî from both fantasy fans and the politically paranoid ‚Äî flourish.
Russell Zimmerman, 41, a writer, game developer and military historian, loves to theorize about ‚ÄúGame of Thrones,‚Äù particularly the books on which it is based, George R.R. Martin‚Äôs series, ‚ÄúA Song of Ice and Fire.‚Äù But some theories are even too much for him, such as one that argues one character (Varys, the spymaster) is secretly a sea creature .
Zimmerman compared the fan theory to a real-life conspiracy theory.
‚ÄúTo me, that's about the level of ‚Äòout there‚Äô crazy-talk as assuming there's a kiddie porn ring in the basement of a pizza shop without a basement,‚Äù he said, referring to the ‚Äúpizzagate‚Äù conspiracy theory that remains popular on the fringes of the far right.
'Game of Thrones' fans gear up for the hit show's end April 12, 2019 02:16 ‚ÄúThrones‚Äù is not the only show with a strong internet following and crackpot theories.
The popular Adult Swim show ‚ÄúRick and Morty‚Äù has various fan guesses at the show‚Äôs secrets. BBC‚Äôs ‚ÄúDoctor Who,‚Äù which follows a time-traveling human-looking alien exploring the universe, has its own theories . And in the early days of the consumer internet, ‚Äú The X-Files ,‚Äù a show that often touched on real-life conspiracy theories, gave birth to some of the first online fan theories .
Meanwhile, any number of real-world conspiracy theories have taken hold among various political and social groups on the internet.
Joseph Uscinski, associate professor of political science at the University of Miami and author of ‚ÄúConspiracy Theories and the People Who Believe Them,‚Äù said diehard fans and conspiracy theorists share a love of extrapolating from the facts in their possession.
‚ÄúConspiracy theories are similar to fan fiction in that they both allow people to make up whatever they want,‚Äù he said.
Uscinski said that whether it‚Äôs ‚ÄúGame of Thrones,‚Äù ‚ÄúStar Wars‚Äù or the JFK assassination, people can take a plot or an event and ‚Äúgo to wherever they want with it.‚Äù
As an example, Uscinski cited Qanon, a remarkably popular genre of conspiracy theories that generally center on a mysterious figure who claims that President Donald Trump is working to uncover a powerful group of pedophiles.
‚ÄúYou have this anonymous poster, Q, who puts out nonsensical clues and people try to make sense of it and try to figure out what happens next,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúThey are enjoying this. They like piecing these things together. It‚Äôs a fan thing for them.‚Äù
Brendon Boutin, 32, who runs a popular ‚ÄúGame of Thrones‚Äù recap channel, ‚ÄúMan of Recaps,‚Äù said the excitement generated by both kinds of theories drove their popularity.
‚ÄúI think the biggest similarity is the feeling you get, the rush of hunting for the truth and discovering secret knowledge,‚Äù Boutin said by email. ‚ÄúI watched some 9/11 ‚ÄòTruth‚Äô videos back in the day, and those brought about the same thrill as discovering Jon Snow's parentage.‚Äù
‚ÄúGame of Thrones‚Äù is far from the only show to have a fervent fanbase that has created its own theories, but few have created a community as rich and active, both online and off. Laurel Steinberg, a New York-based relationship therapist, said the behavior shown by conspiracy theorists and superfans is ‚Äúabsolutely analogous.‚Äù
The only conspiracy theories I entertain are from Game of Thrones
‚Äî Brandon (@JealousCloud) April 5, 2019 ‚ÄúPeople like to feel part of a group, part of a movement, part of a team,‚Äù Steinberg said. ‚ÄúIt feels good to have something that gives them a identity. It feels good to have something to be excited about, and watch develop in real time.‚Äù
But ‚ÄúThrones‚Äù fandom is also susceptible to the same internet dynamics that have spurred ever-more outlandish conspiracy theories, rewarding people who can draw the most attention.
‚ÄúYou're able to create community, and then become an expert. You‚Äôve ridden the tailcoats of the star and then you become a breakout star in that community,‚Äù Steinberg said.‚ÄùYou become an influencer.‚Äù
Chloe Ketchum, 27, who co-hosts a podcast about the series, ‚ÄúGirls Gone Canon,‚Äù said that while she enjoys the feeling of community around ‚ÄúGame of Thrones,‚Äù she‚Äôs also seen the lengths some fans will go to attract a following.
‚ÄúThere are creators that push shock value to get views,‚Äù Ketchum said. ‚ÄúPeople will do anything for attention.‚Äù
While there are similarities in the psychology behind intense fandoms and political conspiracists, Uscinski stressed that they result in divergent behaviors. He said fans will generally abandon theories that don‚Äôt hold up, whereas conspiracy theorists ignore evidence that proves them wrong.
There‚Äôs also the real-world consequences. Conspiracy theories around politics and current events have inspired some people to commit acts of violence , which has led to efforts by politicians and activist groups to force internet platforms to reign in the spread of the disinformation that can fuel the theories.
‚ÄúWhen the show comes out, people will disregard their theories that didn‚Äôt turn out to be true,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúBut with flat earthers, when they do an experiment and it doesn‚Äôt show them what they want, they still hold that belief anyway. They‚Äôre much more invested‚Äù
Ben Kesslen Ben Kesslen writes for NBC News.

title: Active shooter drills are scaring kids and may not protect them. Some schools are taking a new approach.
content:
Heidi Lee Pottinger‚Äôs 5-year-old son was at a football game last fall with his father when, following a touchdown, celebratory fireworks rocketed into the sky. Panicked by the popping sounds, the little boy turned to his dad. ‚ÄúActive shooter!‚Äù he cried, tears in his eyes.
Pottinger‚Äôs son is one of millions of schoolchildren in America who have done active shooter and lockdown drills. The exercises, a legacy of the April 20, 1999, Columbine High School rampage, are intended to prepare teachers and students for the rare threat of a gunman opening fire in their school.
Pottinger‚Äôs son started doing the drills at his private nursery-through-eighth-grade school when he was just 3. During the drills, the Tucson, Arizona, youngster ‚Äî whom Pottinger asked NBC News not to name to protect his privacy ‚Äî would quietly crouch with his classmates and teachers behind furniture, rehearsing what to do if a real shooter were to burst in.
The drills affected him deeply. At home, he bit his nails and did pretend lockdowns while he was playing. Eventually, he refused to go anywhere alone, even to his room or a bathroom at home.
‚ÄúHe would say, ‚ÄòThe lockdown is going to get me,‚Äô‚Äù Pottinger, a maternal and child researcher at the University of Arizona College of Public Health, said. ‚ÄúIt just really caught me off guard. ... This is his childhood and it should be carefree, and it‚Äôs not.‚Äù
Active shooter drills have become more common as school gun massacre after massacre has made headlines. The drills give teachers and students a blueprint to follow during emergencies, which may save lives . Forty-two states have laws requiring some sort of emergency or safety drills in schools, many of which are designed to protect against active shooters, according to the nonprofit Education Commission of the States.
But there is hardly any research on the drills‚Äô effectiveness, and while there are some federal recommendations , there is no standard template for schools to follow in terms of how to do them, how often to conduct them and how to explain them to students of different ages.
Over the past two decades, the drills have ramped up in intensity ‚Äî with some schools going so far as to use fake blood and fire blanks at students . A drill last month at an Indiana school prompted outrage when teachers were shot execution-style with pellet guns , leaving them injured.
Related News News Indiana teachers hurt by Airsoft guns used in active shooter drill say sheriffs went too far At the same time, students‚Äô anxieties have swelled. Some are not told that the lockdowns are just drills, prompting them to send what they believe are final goodbyes over text to their parents or faint or throw up . Others are afraid to go to school in the days following the drills.
As a result, a growing number of schools are experimenting with ways to lessen the toll of the drills while still doing everything possible to keep students safe. For some school districts, that means using age-appropriate language; for others, it involves having guidance counselors or school psychologists available during and after the drills.
But even relatively tame active shooter drills with plenty of warning can traumatize students, critics say, raising the question of whether schools should do them at all.
‚ÄúChildren are much more likely to be abused by a parent than shot at school, to be in a car accident, to be screamed at by a teacher. We don‚Äôt practice that.‚Äù
‚ÄúChildren are much more likely to be abused by a parent than shot at school, to be in a car accident, to be screamed at by a teacher. We don‚Äôt practice that,‚Äù said Joy Levinson, a New York City-based clinical psychologist who has had elementary-age clients tell her they wet their pants in class because drills made them afraid to go down the hall to the bathroom.
‚ÄúIt causes school to feel unsafe, like a place we can‚Äôt learn,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúThat‚Äôs what schools are for.‚Äù
Borrowing police and prison lingo for schools Virtually all public schools in America teach students some form of emergency preparedness, ranging from fire and tornado drills to mock lockdowns.
While drills date back decades ‚Äî students in the 1950s dove under their desks during the Cold War‚Äôs ‚Äúduck-and-cover‚Äù nuclear bomb drills ‚Äî it was only in the past 20 years that ‚Äúactive shooter‚Äù and ‚Äúlockdown‚Äù entered the educational lexicon.
Originally a recreational hunting term, ‚Äúactive shooter‚Äù became part of law enforcement‚Äôs vocabulary after Columbine. The general public, including schools, started using the term several years later, according to Northeastern University criminologist James Alan Fox. At first, schools simply called the exercises ‚ÄúColumbine drills,‚Äù he said.
Students and faculty run out of Columbine High School during a shooting rampage by two teenagers on April 20, 1999. Gary Caskey / Reuters, file ‚ÄúLockdown‚Äù drills, borrowed from prison jargon, later became regularly used to refer to a rehearsal for anything that might require students and teachers to stay put in a classroom with locked doors, closed windows, lights turned off and blinds drawn ‚Äî such as nearby police activity, a natural disaster or an active shooter.
No matter what they‚Äôre called, the objective of the drills is clear: to protect students and teachers.
Fox argues that there is no way to prove active shooter drills work, because it would be impossible to conduct such an experiment. But some who have come face to face with gun violence say they are certain the drills saved lives.
When a gunman rushed toward a schoolyard full of children at Rancho Tehama Elementary in Corning, California, in November 2017, staff immediately ushered students inside. They implemented lockdown procedures they had rehearsed as the gunman shot at the building.
One student was shot in the chest and foot and survived. But no one else was hurt ‚Äî something Corning Union Elementary School District Superintendent Richard Fitzpatrick credited to staff, who he said ‚Äúflawlessly‚Äù locked down the school after years of practice.
Many parents also support drills, saying it‚Äôs necessary for children to understand the dangers they could face.
‚ÄúI think it‚Äôs important to have a plan," Sarah Caron, whose son survived the Sandy Hook Elementary shooting in 2012, told Today.com last year, "even if it is ultimately deviated from.‚Äù
Are drills causing more harm than good? Still, the backlash to active shooter drills has grown, amid criticism that they are particularly traumatic for children given that it‚Äôs hard to shield them from news coverage of mass shootings happening around the country.
‚ÄúThe tragedies are happening not just in public schools, but at a movie house down the street, at a nightclub,‚Äù said Lily Eskelsen Garcia, president of the National Education Association , which represents more than 3 million teachers and education support professionals.
‚ÄúWhen they know what has happened from Columbine to Parkland and that crazed people have walked through schools," she said, "this is something that reminds them, ‚ÄòI could be killed every time I walk into school,‚Äô even if there is a .0001 chance that this will ever happen to them.‚Äù (Last year, the Washington Post estimated the odds of a public school student getting shot and killed since 1999 to be about 1 in 614,000,000.)
Related News News Parkland students mock new security measure ‚Äî clear backpacks The lack of rules for the drills has also caused problems.
Some schools do not notify teachers and students in the days beforehand, based on state laws that require the drills to be conducted without prior warning. Once a drill starts, administrators might announce over the loudspeaker that it‚Äôs just an exercise. Or they might not: When two Wisconsin schools held ‚ÄúCode Red,‚Äù or school violence, drills in October 2018 without telling teachers and students that they were just drills, enraged parents wrote a letter to the school district , blaming it for ‚Äúcreating a false sense of trauma in staff and students for the sake of ‚Äòmaking it seem real‚Äô or in order to have people ‚Äòtake it seriously.‚Äô‚Äù (A bill introduced earlier this month would give Wisconsin school administrators the ability to warn students beforehand.)
Some worry that too much emphasis on active shooter drills comes at the expense of preparing for more probable situations that schools may face, such as a noncustodial parent trying to sign a child out of school, a pupil choking or an extreme weather event.
‚ÄúWhat people should be practicing are functions,‚Äù Michael Dorn, executive director of school-safety consulting firm Safe Havens International, said. ‚ÄúWhat we suggest to people to do is you have an array of protective actions, lockdowns, evacuations, reverse evacuations, where you practice going back into the building when the danger is outside.‚Äù
He discouraged simulating real shootings, which may look very different in reality than they did during the simulation.
‚ÄúIt can have the reverse effect of what you want,‚Äù Dorn said. ‚ÄúYou not only induce trauma, but people will be less able to survive if they encounter the real threat.‚Äù
‚ÄòDon‚Äôt be scared, be prepared‚Äô: Lessening the anxiety Some educators and school safety experts are experimenting with ways to minimize students‚Äô stress.
At Liberty Central School District in Liberty, New York, the district‚Äôs motto for drills is ‚ÄúDon‚Äôt be scared, be prepared.‚Äù Teachers tell the more than 1,800 students in the district in advance about the drills, giving them a general time frame for when to expect them. They review their purpose, as well as the procedures, superintendent of schools Augustine Tornatore said.
‚ÄúThese are tough conversations to have, but it‚Äôs important elementary school students know that if something bad is happening, that they have a way of dealing with it,‚Äù he said.
But the district recognizes some children will still have anxiety during the drills, Tornatore said, so school guidance counselors, social workers and psychologists follow up with students afterward. There is also sensory support and occupational support in classrooms for students with special needs during the drills, such as giving a student who tends to feel anxious a ball to squeeze.
At the 6,800-student Oak Creek-Franklin joint school district just south of Milwaukee, Wisconsin, teachers tailor drills to the youngest students, calling them ‚Äúbuddy room drills‚Äù so they sound less scary. The term is used to practice anything that requires quickly moving, say from one classroom to another or inside from the playground, assistant superintendent for operations Daniel Unertl said.
Another option, according to some school safety experts, is to leave students out of active shooter drills altogether.
‚ÄúThere‚Äôs no evidence that they work, and if the real thing does happen, when adrenaline is pumping, all those lessons learned can be forgotten.‚Äù
Fox, the Northeastern criminologist, does not see how students benefit from them, arguing that teachers can learn just as well to practice for these events from their local police departments without students being traumatized in the process.
‚ÄúThere‚Äôs no evidence that they work, and if the real thing does happen, when adrenaline is pumping, all those lessons learned can be forgotten,‚Äù he said.
‚ÄúIt doesn‚Äôt mean you shouldn‚Äôt do anything ‚Äî it would be just as effective if you just told kids what happens in the case of an active shooter,‚Äù he added, just as safety videos on planes don‚Äôt involve passengers actually rehearsing an evacuation.
Pottinger, the Arizona mom, said talking through her son‚Äôs fears and giving him coping strategies (including telling him to envision an imaginary cloud keeping watch over him) helped him to not be as nervous. She has switched her son to a preschool closer to home but does not blame his previous school, which she believes was just doing what administrators felt was in the kids‚Äô best interest.
Still, she said, seeing the effect that the drills had on her son was ‚Äúreally concerning.‚Äù
‚ÄúI do understand that these protocols are unfortunately becoming more normal and needed,‚Äù she said, ‚Äúbut I think there are other strategies that can be implemented.‚Äù
CORRECTION (April 15, 2019, 11:30 a.m. ET): An earlier version of this article misspelled the name of an Arizona city. It is Tucson, not Tuscon.
